Description:
"Four row houses collapse into the Mill Creek sewer near 50th and Funson St when the street crumbles beneath them....The first collapse that I could find happened in 1912; the last in 1961. Over the course of those fifty years there were at least nine cave ins over the length of the sewer. At least four people were killed, one ice cream truck fell in, at least two private vehicles fell in (including one which was never recovered, even having been searched for by police in a 14-foot aluminum rowboat in the sewer the following year). Well over 50 buildings were condemned, hundreds of people were forced to move, and in at least two cases the exposed sewer was left open for months at a time after the ground had collapsed(in one case, for at least a year - literally a chasm was opened at the foot of peoples homes, raw sewage flowing through it for a year."

I cannot think of anything more unsettling than literally having the ground fall out under ones feet. Reading that paragraph was an experience in ongoing shock. 

Image of open sewer as reminder of death/not being in as much control of the world as we like to believe.
Source: "Mill Creek Sewer - Building Collapse Jul, 1961 Funson Street" and "Mill Creek Sewer - Miscel" at Temple University Urban Archives.
Title: Row Houses Collapse

Description: A wagoner, next to a stage coach driver, was a man of immense importance, and they were inclined to be clanish.  They would not hesitate to unite against landlord, stage driver or coachman who might cross their path, as is instanced in the case when a wedding party were on their way to Philadelphia...When one of the gentlemen drivers, the foremost one (possibly the groom), but not of necessity, was paying more attention to his fair companion than his horses he drove against the leaders of one of the numerous wagons that were passing on in the same direction. It was an unpardonable offense and nothing short of an encounter in the stave yard or in front of the hotel could atone for such a breach of highway ethics, and at a point where the party stopped to rest before continuing their journey the wagoners overtook them and they immediately called on the gentleman for redress. But seeing one of the party they had known they claimed they would excuse him on his friend’s account, but the party offending would not have it so, and said no friend of his should excuse him from getting a beating if he deserved it, and I have no doubt he prided himself on his muscular abilities also. However, it was peaceably arranged and each pursued their way without any blood being shed or bones broken. That was one of the many similar occurrences which happened daily, many not ending so harmlessly.
Source: A. Exton Witmer. "The Old Turnpike." In Papers Read before the Lancaster County Historical Society on Nov. 5th, 1897 vol. 2 no. 3 (1897): 76-77.

Description: It was considered a lasting disgrace for one of the stage taverns to entertain a wagoner and sure to lose the patronage of the better class of travel, should such become known. As soon as he had taken his departure the hostlers and stable boys were put to work to clean up every vestige of straw or litter in front of the hotel that would be an indication of having entertained a wagoner over night.

"By 1900 the railroad stations along the Main Line were in place, a string of pearls beckoning to all who wished to take advantage of the beautiful new neighborhoods that surrounded each station...Thousands of residents looked to Philadelphia for their income and to their new homes for comfort and leisure. And those train riders learned a new mnemonic to help them remember the 17 stations that meant "home": Old Maids Never Wed And Have Babies; Really Vicious Retrievers Snap Willingly, Snarl Dangerously, Beagles Don't, Period. In order from the the first stop after 30th Street Station, the original station names are Overbrook, Merion, Narberth, Wynnewood, Ardmore, Haverford, Bryn Mawr, Rosemont, Villanova, Radnor, St. Davids, Wayne, Strafford, Devon, Berwyn, Daylesford, and Paoli."

Here we see the beginning of the commute for the Main Line. The need to create a mnemonic to remember all of the train stops in order reflects the spread of the populace outside of Philadelphia.

Description:
“Some famous lady—who was it?—used to say of anyone she richly despised that he was a ‘saunterer.’ I suppose she meant he was a mere trifler, a lounger, an idle stroller of the streets. It is an ignominious confession, but I am a confirmed saunterer. I love to be set down haphazard among unknown byways; to saunter with open eyes, watching the moods and the humors of men, the shapes of their dwellings, the criss-cross of their streets. It is an implanted passion that grows keener and keener. The everlasting lure of round-the-corner, how fascinating it is!” The saunterer as the Philadelphian flâneur? A detective of sorts, maybe a physiognomist, too—but note his manner of sauntering.
On a different note: “Just as Thoreau compiled a Domesday Book and kind of classified directory of the sights, sounds and scents of Walden (carefully recording the manners of a sandback and the prejudices of a woodlouse or an apple tree) so I love to annotate the phenomena of the city. I can be as solitary in a city street as ever Thoreau was in Walden.” Why were these ephemera worth recording?
Source: Morley, Travels (Philadelphia, David McKay, 1920), 10
Title: The saunterer

Description: “One who was nourished along the line of the Paoli local, who knew it long before it became electrified with those spider-leg trolleys on its roof and before the Wynnewood embankments were lined with neat little garages, sometimes has an inner pang that it is getting a bit too civilized. And yet no train will ever mean to us what that does! The saying that was good enough for Queen Mary and Mr. Browning is good enough for me. When I die, you will find the words PAOLI LOCAL indelibled on my heart. When the Cortisan patriot’s bicentennial comes along, in 1925, I hope there will be a grand reunion of all the old travelers along that line. The railroad will run specially decorated trains and distribute souvenirs among commuters of more than forty years’ standing. The campus of Haverford College will be the scene of a mass-meeting. There will be reminiscent addresses by those who recall when the tracks ran along Railroad avenue at Haverford and up through Preston. An express agent will be barbecued, and there will be dancing and song and passing of the mead cup until far into the night.”

Description:
In 1681 William Penn sells 30,000 acres to a group of Welsh Quakers, promising them "that they might establish a Welsh "barony" which should have religious freedom and complete local self-government"(4). 

Edward Jones leads the first four families of Welsh Quakers abroad the ship "Lyon" to Upland, arriving on August 13th, 1682, two months before William Penn founds the City of Philadelphia. 

William Penn never gives the Welsh autonomy, although they go onto found a separate and distinct community in Merion, which grows co-currently with Philadelphia. 

Merion, Radnor, Cynwyd, Bryn Mawr and Haverford all owe there names to this Welsh community.
Source:
d’Apéry, Tello J., M.D. 1936. Overbrook Farms: Its Historical Background, 
Growth and Community Life. Overbrook Farms, Philadelphia: The Magee Press.
Title: Dr. Edward Jones sails for America

Description: The locomotive George Washington, designed by William Norris, ascends the inclined plane, something Trautwine claims "the engineers did not dream that a locomotive could ascend." "No one would believe Norris when he told them what the new locomotive had done. They said his tale was a fabrication on the face of it, since it was perfectly obvious that a locomotive simply could not ascend an inclined plane solely by its own power. Even after the fact had been repeated in the presence of many witnesses it could scarcely be credited. Eight months after Norris had demonstrated that a locomotive could not only climb an ascending grade by its own power, but could also haul a train up, A.G. Steere, of the Erie Railway, in a long communication to the Railroad Journal of MArch 11, 1837, proved by elaborate algebraic formulae that it could not; and that no other locomotive ever could climb an ascending grade by its own power."
Source: John C. Trautwine, "The Philadelphia and Columbia Railroad of 1834," Philadelphia History Vol. 2, No. 7 (1925); Philadelphia City History Society; Charles Frederick Carter, When Railroads Were New (New York: Simmons-Boardman Publishing Co., 1926), as compiled by Bennett Smith.

Description:
An 80-year-old retired wagoner recalled a night from his youth when he stopped at the tavern near Hand’s Pass: 
“Having had their supper they unrolled their mattressses [sic] on the barroom floor, which all wagoners at that time carried with them, prepared for a night’s repose, doubtless having listened, prior to this, while sitting around the large open fire, to tales of various murders and spectral appearances which had occurred or been seen at different points along this much-traveled highway. Perhaps the warm toddy, which was always at hand, assisted a little with the marvelous tales related. However, when all was quiet in doors and out, as far as could be with the various teams feeding by the wagons, suddenly a succession of piercing shrieks came from the stable yard, and every wagoner who had been snoring to his heart’s content on his separate mattress sprang to his feet, and, rushing to the door, saw a wild scene of confusion going on in the yard and in front of the old tavern. Horses were prancing, … upsetting the feed trough and tangled in the harness or fastenings of their companions on the other side, while shriek after shriek of a most startling nature came from a dark corner in the yard near which the dense woods terminated. Some even claimed they saw a white object of various dimensions, but the narrator said he lost no time in investigating, but, with others, hastily rolled up his mattress, attached his horses to the wagon, and, after settling his sore with the landlord…started out into the night, although it neared ‘the witching time of night when churchyards yawn, etc’ and did not again draw rein until he arrived at the next stopping place."
Source: A. Exton Witmer, "The Old Turnpike" in Papers Read Before the Lancaster County Historical Society on Nov. 5, 1897, Vol. 2, No. 3 (1897), 82-83.
Title: The Haunted Forest

Description:
The Philadelphia General Strike of 1910

In mid-February of 1910 angry trolley workers began rioting following the breakdown of negotiations between trolley workers and PRT (Pennsylvania Rapid Transit) and PRT's refusal to unionize. Riots broke out all over the city with Lancaster Avenue being host to a good deal of the violence. An article in the Philadelphia Inquirer reads: "Cars were attacked and clashes occurred between the police and mobs at Fifty-second and Lancaster avenue...cars were wrecked at Forty-third street and Lancaster avenue, Fortieth and Lancaster avenue...William Janz, a "strike-breaking" motorman, whose home is in New York, was probably fatally injured by a brick striking him on the head when his car was attacked by rioters..."

 From a basic standpoint, the general strike marks a shift in the balance of power in labor. The size of the strike shows that these workers were no longer willing to let the PRT continue to ignore their concerns. Yet, the fact that strike became a series of riots and that extreme violence that took place unmask an incredibly dark side of modernity. The workers achieved their goals in the end, but at the price of injuring others and destroying parts of the city.
Source: “Many Are Injured in Series of Riots.” The Philadelphia Inquirer. February 28, 1910, sec. 2. America’s Historical Newspapers.
Title: Mobs and Bricks

Description:
"With the passing of Wistar Morris in 1887, parcels of his land (which had been in the family since the original land grants of William Penn in the late 1600's) were sold to several individuals. In 1889 the Childs and Drexel Syndicate purchased from the Morris family and other adjacent landowners the area now included between 58th Street and 66th Street, City Line and Woodbine Avenue. This suburban, or more accurately, rural area called Overbrook Farms, was to be developed into a gracious community of large custom-built homes. In 1890, such a large undertaking was a bold innovation. By 1893, the developers realized that no real community would ever develop without sufficient churches. So they offered land to several denominations with the condition for each that a stone church would be erected within one year at a cost of not less than $25,000 – equivalent to perhaps millions with the economic situation as it is. This proposal was made for purely business reasons.
 
"During these same years a number of Catholic families had purchased homes in Overbrook farms. And in those Victorian times of large household staffs, many members of these staffs were Catholics. Both groups found the trip to the parish church, Our Lady of the Rosary, at 63rd and Callowhill Streets, quite arduous, and frequently in winter almost impossible. They therefore petitioned Archbishop Ryan on several occasions to erect a chapel closer to this new community.
 
"Thus, by early 1894, these two groups, prompted by quite different if not opposite motives, inspired the Archbishop to appoint the young curate at St. Agatha's parish in West Philadelphia, the Rev. James A. Mullin, as founding pastor of the new parish in Overbrook, St. Mary Magdalene's. The date was April 14, 1894."

Description:
"Many visitors, however, told valiant stories from Quaker history- about William Penn being thrown in Newgate Prison for preaching on a London street or Philadelphia abolitionist Lucretia Mott walking arm in arm with a black woman into the face of a proslavery mob. Rufus determined to be that sort of Quaker."

Which sort of Quaker would that be? William Penn the noted misogynist?(1) 

Historicality becomes vacated in order to create an ideal, simultaneously rooted in the past yet materializing in the future. Figures are mythologized through atrophied accounts of their lives in order to convey the sort of beings which we should aim at becoming. The lives of men become signifiers and the signified becomes a product of dominant values. That which doesn't fit these mythologies is hidden away in the nooks of history.

Description: Christopher Morley on his idle time at Haverford College: “In so far as any formal or systematic discipline of thought was concerned, I think I may say my education was a complete failure. For this I had only my own smattering and desultory habit of mind to blame and also a vivid troublesome sense of the beauty of it all. The charm of the prismatic fringe round the edges made juggling with the lens too tempting, and a clear persistent focus was never attained. Considered (oddly enough) by my mates as the pattern of a diligent scholar, I was in reality as idle as the idlest of them, which is saying much; though I confess that my dilettantism was not wholly disreputable. My mind excellently exhibited the Heraclitean doctrine: a constant flux of information passed through it, but nothing remained. Indeed, my senses were so continually crammed with new enchanting impressions, and every field of knowledge seemed so alluring, it was not strange I made little progress in any.” Idleness disguised as diligent scholarship: dilettantism. Morley plays a transparent medium for knowledge to pass through without leaving a trace. Compare mediumship to collecting and capitalist accumulation—and keep in mind that Morley denies progress. Pay heed to the pleasure involved in Morley’s promiscuity.
Source: Christopher Morley, “The Autogenesis of a Poet,” in his Plum pudding: of divers ingredients, discreetly blended & seasoned (Golden City, New York: Double Day, Page and Co'y, 1922), 5–6.

Description: A newspaper in Newark, N.J. published an article in 1921 unveiling the Lancaster view on early railroads. It received “hot denial” from Lancaster officials and residents, but read something like this: “If the society wants the use of the schoolhouse to debate some decent, moral question we should cheerfully give the use of it, but such a thing as a railroad is WICKED AS WELL AS ABSURD. If God had wanted human beings to travel at the fearful rate of seven miles per hour, He would have clearly foretold it by his prophets, but since nothing is said about it in Holy write, it is plainly an invention of the devil to lead immortal souls to hell. Hence, we must refuse use of the schoolhouse”(101). At the time of this article, Lancaster had still not incorporated the railroad into its Public Works. Description:
"Apparitions and poltergeist-like disturbances were reported by the owner and 
employees of a wayside inn in Merion, Pensylvannia. The legend that a “ghost” haunted the 
premises had persisted for more than 2 centuries. Quantitative measures tested 3 sensitives and 3 
controls. Participants marked on floor plans locations where they sensed a ghost (sensitives) or 
where they believed a credulous person might report a ghost (controls). Participants also responded 
to a checklist containing brief descriptions of the reported phenomena that were randomly 
interposed with descriptions of plausible disturbances that no one had reported. One sensitive’s 
floor-plan responses significantly resembled the locations of disturbances reported by witnesses (p 
= .026), and her checklist impressions suggested the ghostly characteristics witnesses had described 
(p = .059). The combined floor-plan responses of sensitives bore a suggestive correspondence to the 
witnesses’ reports (p = .084). Control participants, neither individually nor as a group, produced 
test responses that resembled the witnesses’ accounts. No significant differences in the magnitudes 
of magnetic fields at target and control sites were found for peak magnitudes, mean magnitudes, or 
all measured magnitudes. These findings imply that the aberrant cognitive phenomena reported by 
witnesses cannot be attributed to variations in the magnitudes of ambient magnetic fields."
Source: Maher, Michaeleen C. "Quantitative Investigation of the General Wayne Inn." Parapsychological Association. N.p., n.d. Web. 7 Oct. 2014. <http://www.parapsych.org/PDF/General_Wayne_Inn.pdf>.
Title: The Science Behind the Ghosts

Description:
"Rumors have swirled about the subterranean zones of Bryn Mawr since the founding of the College, and campus ghost stories tend to involve basements. Lena Barnard ’12 shares a story of a secret love affair gone wrong when a student’s boyfriend died in a fire in the basement of Denbigh. In December 2004, Anna Mendoza ’08 wrote in The College News of a rumored death during construction of the Pembroke and Rockefeller dormitories.... These [basements and the tunnels connecting them] are considered to be extremely dangerous, which is why curious students who have attempted to delve further below the first floor of certain buildings are usually stopped by locked doors... But locked doors and warnings have not stopped some students from attempting to foray into these forbidden areas... A popular and precarious method of getting into lower levels is the use of the dumbwaiter. Despite the blaring precaution that the weight carried should not exceed 75 pounds, students still hop in...  Within the last five years there was an incident in which a Haverford student got stuck in the dumbwaiter of Merion [Dorm]. The realistic possibility of electrocution or losing limbs should serve as a fair warning to those contemplating going into off-limit sections of the campus."

Something about the supernatural appeals deeply enough to some part of our psyche that people are willing to risk their physical safety in the pursuit of these mystical beings. Also, it is interesting to note the religious foundations of these stories and their connection to the idea of purgatory. The rites and rituals of burial must be followed otherwise one might be stuck in this realm. Those who violate societal norms must be made an example in order to demarcate the boundaries of the community. A binding together of the community through distancing of those who fail to adhere to custom.
Source: Chu, Vicky. "Tunneling Through The Ghosts of Bryn Mawr." The Bi-College News. N.p., 24 Nov. 2008. Web. 8 Oct. 2014.

Description:
External shots/settings of two scenes from M. Night Shayamalan's The Sixth Sense (1999) starring Bruce Willis and Haley Joel Osment

External shot of the supermarket: Cole (Haley Joel Osment) and his mother (Toni Collete) leave the grocery store with a cart filled with groceries. It is autumn as evidenced by the pumpkins. Perhaps Halloween is coming up? The shot precedes the incident in the car where Cole sees his mother accidently run over a pregnant woman crossing the street, unable to break in time. The frightened boy then discovers that there is no pregnant woman and that his screams were what caused his mother to break suddenly. Note: The old Acme was demolished in 2011 to make way for a larger and newer one.

External/Internal shots of the Dead Girl's (Mischa Barton) house: Cole and Malcolm (Bruce Willis) arrive at funerial gathering at a suburban home. Mourners gather to console the parents of a young girl who has passed away from illness. Cole presents the father with a tape that reveals the true circumstances of his daughter's death. Once the truth is revealed, another external shot of the house shows Cole offering reassurance to the Dead Girl's little sister on a swingset in the front yard.

It is worth noting that the supermarket and the suburban home are quintessential elements of modernity on the Main Line. In the supermarket, the size of the store and range of food products available embody modern notions of convenience and commoditization of food. The suburban home conjures up Leave-It-to-Beaver-esque images of the happy family and the safe, pristine neighborhoods. Further, the position of these shots before/during pivotal paranormal scenes shows how ghosts of evil and tragedy can lurk in even the most "normal" places. This is especially true in the case of the Dead Girl, whose normal home and beautiful mother hide a deadly secret.
Source: G, Yuri. “Movie Tourist: The Sixth Sense (1999).” Movie Tourist, July 18, 2013. http://movie-tourist.blogspot.com/2013/07/the-sixth-sense-1999.html.

Description:
A newspaper clipping reporting the street battle between a local cat (whose residence was on Lancaster Avenue around 37th street) and an owl over a rat. 
The cat was returning from a stable with his recent kill when the owl swooped in. The cat fought gallantly, but the owl managed to wrestle the rat away, taking (injured) wing to the trees above. When the neighbors discovered the wounded cat, he was missing an eye and chunks of skin. 

This situation is too hilarious and silly for words. It becomes more hilarious when one compares it to the romantic rendezvous between an owl and cat in the famous Edward Lear poem "The Owl and the Pussycat", which, by the way, was published 45 years before this incident. 
In all seriousness, the struggle between a domesticated cat and a wild bird of prey seems to speak to the struggle between man (in the form of modern urbanization) and nature. Modernity and urban sprawl has created the domesticated cat that stalks the alleyways and wild animals that have no choice but to navigate the urban sprawl that has encroached on their habitat.
Source: Inquirer, From the Philadelphia. “CAT LOSES EYE TO OWL.: Bitter Fight Between Bird and Feline Over Possession of a Rat.” The Washington Post (1877-1922). November 2, 1915.

Description:
Painting by American Modernist Alice Neel in response to her child's death.

Story of child's death goes from Philadelphia to Cuba and back again. Does she or her lover meet Antonio Guiteras along the way?

Alice meets Carlos Enriquez at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Art's summer school in Chester Springs. They soon marry and return to Havana to live with Enriquez family,  where they are welcomed by the blossoming cuban avant-garde movement. They live with Enriquez wealthy family, though return to the States after the birth of their first child, who soon dies of diphtheria. 

Enriquez famous artist in his own right. Flee's to Cuba with couple's second daughter in 1930, severing contact, though the couple never officially divorced and never does. 

In response Alice suffers a nervous breakdown, tries to kill herself, and spends the next 18 months in Philadelphia insane asylum. Upon release she becomes one of the first American artists to take part in the Work's Progress Administration, and is hired to paint a new piece every six weeks. 

Spends rest of life as communist sympathiser and bohemian artist, appears in film with Allen Ginsberg, awarded National Woman's Caucus for Art Award by then President Jimmy Carter and and dies just as she rises to critical acclaim. 

Why is she interesting?

-Father accountant for Pennsylvania Railroad, which serves as major conduit of wealth along the Mainline

-Suicide attempt makes sense in light of losing husband/child, but what can we read out of husband's return to Cuba? Why did he leave? Investigate. 

-Cuba. Young man born in Lower Merion moves to Cuba to become revolutionary. Another young man is sent from Cuba to the United States to receive an education. Brings back American bride. Cuban avant-garde, cuban revolutionary, both along the Mainline. 


Alice Neel and Mary Cassatt, both educated by Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, both raised along Mainline, both families involved in Pennsylvania Railroad. Offset by a generation they represent the face of art immediately before and immediately after the moment of modernity.

Description:
The military foundation of "turnpike;" weaponry and violence give us our names for these transportation arteries.

"The origin of the word goes back to England in the 14th Century, when the first turnpike, or road on which toll was charged, was established.  At that time, the principal weapon of the infantry was a wooden shaft, 15 or 20 feet long, called a pike.  A turnpike was a name given to a revolving barrier, consisting of three or more horizontal bars, sharpened at one end like pikes.  these barriers were placed on the first roads where the tolls were taken from the users of the highways.  They were followed by gates or single bars, but the name has lived on in the shortened form of 'Pike.'"

Not the sort to be caught with what investigators say they found: eight pounds of marijuana, 23 grams of cocaine, 11 grams of ecstasy, three grams of hash oil, $11,000 in cash, two AR-15 rifles, one handgun and loads of ammo."

This story plays into the larger narrative in which issues systemically plaguing low-income areas, such as drugs and gun violence, only receiving media attention when they afflict the middle/upper classes.

Description:
Vachel Lindsay was an American poet, father of singing poetry. He wrote to Christopher Morley who was writing for The Public Ledger in Philadelphia at the time. “Believe me, my dear boy, I am very lonely. More and more I am dependent on human beings ONE AT A TIME, and unless a friend cares enough to spend whole days with me as you have done, and especially walking as you have done, I am lonely indeed. I suppose it is a reaction from the peculiar ecstacy of a completely sympathetic series of audiences. It seems to create the craving for the very opposite, one very personal human creature, at a time, and I certainly hate myself alone, as I did not once do. For reasons not to be set down here, and bore such a successfully married person as yourself, I have every reason to let the romantic side of life alone for a year or two at least, and I am peculiarly dependent on out doors and adventure, and nothing is an adventure alone anymore, especially the matter of pleasing a few English literati, who do not exist for me except as through the eyes such as you and Mrs. Morley.”

In an earlier letter he wrote: “My Dear Morley: Remember we take a walk, if all is well, Sunday Morning the 23rd of February”

Description:
Bryn Mawr Summer School Student Marion Jackson's Personal Autobiography, "It Set Me Thinking," 1937. While Jackson initially thought she was "awakened" to the true meaning of a Bryn Mawr education from the welcoming lectures by deans and professors, it turns out through collective sharing within the dorm environment, she realizes her own unique awakening:

"I was walking through the hall in Denbigh on Tuesday afternoon when the girl in room 13 called to me. She wanted to know what I could tell her about the Scottsboro case and about Angelo Herndon, the Negro organizer. I am a Negro; still I was forced to confess that there was very little I could tell her. Many of us feel that the Negro problem is a tremendous one and we feel so helpless in regard to it that we take the easiest way out and shut our eyes to much of the real suffering of our people. Of course, we know that is the wrong way to look  upon the matter; but then too often we feel that we are only one tenth of the population, and that is a very small minority, then the girl in room 13 reminded me of the fact that nearly 90 percent of the Negro population were workers, and the workers are the masses. Therefore we need only to unite our forces and we will bring about a better treatment of conditions for all. Through unity of forces we can break down race discrimination and class discrimination.
I am glad my sister student called me into her room that day. She set me thinking in an entirely different direction. I no longer think in terms of dollars and cents. I think in terms of what I can do for my class and my race. I feel that I too can do my part, be it ever too small. I feel that I will have accomplished a great deal if I am able to convince other Negroes that we as a race must stop sitting down and taking it on the chin, so to speak.
We must stop looking for the path of easiness, for we must face facts and learn truths—know the cause in order to find a cure.
I intend therefore on returning home to connect myself with the National Negro Congress and to learn Negro history, since what education I do have I have received in the public schools and any favorable facts pertaining to the Negro were very intentionally omitted.
I have then to take Bryn Mawr for putting me on the right track.
I have Bryn Mawr to thank for making me race and class conscious.”

This chance encounter is crucial for Jackson's own awakening process. However, it should be noted that what Jackson takes from this chance encounter, this communal coming together of minds, is not the implicitly white (or at least non-black) student's exact doctrine of how class and race ought to operate. In her criticism of this narrative, Karyn Hollis notes that there is a break between the Room 13 girl's idea of race concerns as assimilated into a greater class narrative, versus Jackson's distinct division between the two. A sense of skepticism for the dominant narrative of history is then therefore imparted on how she shares with others. Veiled histories and truth of experience. Subjectivity as necessary to understand individual and collective. ∆Thesis on the Philosophy of History∆
Source: Hollis, Karyn. "Autobiography and Reconstructing Subjectivity at the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers 1921-1938." In What We Hold in Common: An Introduction to Working-class Studies. Edited by Janet Zandy. Third ed. New York: Feminist Press at the City University of New York, 2001. 88.
Title: Room 13 and Community Enlightenment

Description:
The boys of St. John's Orphan Asylum convalesce at Louisa Gratz's country estate.

A published report from the orphanage's Board of Managers recounts the rise in health issues among the boys and heiress Louisa Gratz's charitable loan of her country estate to the orphanage. The boys and the nuns stayed at the mansion for a few weeks.

Despite the amusing image of a mansion filled with orphan boy, the origins of the benefactor prove to be the most interesting part of this story. Louisa Gratz was not just any heiress, but, as her obituary states, the daughter of prominent Jewish businessman Simon Gratz. She was also the niece of Rebecca Gratz, one of Philadelphia's leading philanthropists and educators in the early 19th century. So, not only did a rich woman help orphans, but also a prominent Jewish family crossed religious lines to help a Catholic organization.

Description:
Bryn Mawr Summer School student, Sarah Gordon, a Russian Jew interested in leftist thought. From her 1929 autobiographic essay "A typical day in my life":

 “I love to observe people’s faces; it is almost like reading books. I always wonder what is going on beyond their calm exteriors. I also like to observe what people are reading, for almost everybody is reading in the train. I have learned to classify people by their reading….But I? I read all these people. Out of the train I come up to my shop, full of impressions.”

Description:
In the summer of 1832, 57 irish immigrant workers died during the construction of the railroad within a six week span. 

 "Two of the skulls discovered had damage consistent with blunt-force trauma, which calls into question reports that everyone in the crew fell victim to the widespread Asiatic cholera outbreak that ravaged Philadelphia that summer. Archival research, a long-covert railroad file and the subsequent archeological discoveries all point to the possibility that anti-immigrant and anti-Catholic sentiment and violence were directed at the men, who would’ve been exotic threats to the locals. Even more shockingly, the railroad itself may have acted to halt the spread of cholera by preemptively killing the infected, figuring the men were expendable and untraceable, and the assailants’ crimes erasable—with fill."

These workers were anonymously buried along the tracks. These deaths "were seen as unfortunate casualties of progress," as if the tides of progress possess some sort of inertia that justifies the deaths of these men. Here, progress is founded on the lives of the 'othered' and subjugated laborer who remains anonymous and is condemned to the shadows of history.

The supernatural enters this space of shadow. "The Rev. J. Francis Watson would finally get his chance to examine the confidential railroad file long stored in a Narberth study and passed down by his grandfather. With it, his twin brother, William, would come to understand his supernatural sighting at Immaculata University two years prior, as townhouses surrounding Duffy’s Cut were going up. Frank would remember his grandfather’s Thanksgiving Day railroad ghost stories, both siblings would recall the walks they took with him on defunct rail."
Source: Pirro, J.F. "Lost and Found." Www.mainlinetoday.com. Main Line Today, n.d. Web. 29 Oct. 2014.

The murderers were brilliant and, according to observers, sociopathic - a charismatic English teacher named William S. Bradfield, and the principal, Dr. Jay C. Smith, of the high school in Upper Merion, Pa., where, along with Mrs. Reinert, they were colleagues.

As usual, the villains are what interest us most...' We want to untangle their twisted minds and strip away the complex layers of their deceptions. We want to understand them and remove all doubt as to their motives."

The condemnation of the murdered and the celebration of the murderer. The killer was brilliant for his plot. How could the woman be so naive? The alienation of the author from the victims is all too common. Our sense of the worldhood of the World has been fragmented  by the modern. Sympathy is not an option in the modern landscape that valorizes such cold rationality evidenced by the killer. Detached rationality becomes fetishized. We can't take our eyes away.

"What is now called the 'Main Line,' was not so designated fifty years ago, as the Pennsylvania Railroad had only one line then and comparatively few city families lived on it, even for the summer months. the country it serves was called by the first settles 'The Welsh Barony,' which consisted of 30,000 acres, and some of the present residents have their deeds signed by William Penn, while their country places are called by Welsh names of places from which their ancestors migrated and some railroad stations have been given these names."

History begins with the colonization by Europeans. The renaming of the territory alienates the land from its past history. Also, the names are rewritten as modernity evolves.

Also, the centrality William Penn to the colonizing of the region is striking.

Description:
"Ardmore: A small town in Ireland on the Atlantic Coast.

Berwyn: Name of a mountain range forming the border between Merioneth and Montgomery counties in Wales.

Bryn Mawr: name given to his plantation by Rowland Ellis after his home in Wales. Means 'high moor,' or 'great hill.'

Devon: Named for a tourist resort in England.

Haverford: Derived from Haverfordwest in Pembrokeshire, Wales, meaning 'the goat's ford.'

Merion: Grandson of a 5th century Welsh prince, from Merionethshire in Wales. 

Narberth: Town in Dyfed, Wales. Name means sacred or consecrated place. 

Paoli: Named for General Pasquale Paoli, a Corsican patriot. 

Radnor: means 'red earth,' Named for the county Radnorshire, located in central Wales. 

Rosemont: Name Given by Pennsylvania Railroad to its station as a compliment to Joshua Ashbridge, whose farm was called Rosemont and who deeded land in 1863 for a station. 

Villanova: From the Augustinian College of St. Thomas of Villa Nova. St. Thomas was a 16th century Spanish bishop. 

Wayne: Named for Anthony Wayne, a Revolutionary War general.

Wynnewood: Wynne Wood was name of plantation named for Dr. Thomas Wynne. "

Welsh and English roots.

Constitutive moment in American history are immortalized through names such as Wayne and Paoli. 

Lenape names all along the Main Line have been erased.
Source: The First 300: The Amazing and Rich History of Lower Merion. Ardmore, Pa: The Society, 2000. Print.

Description:
In 1887, J. Johnson Brown owned the plot of land straddling Lancaster Ave. and the St. David's/Villanova exit of the Blue Route.  The estate house, "Vanor," sat on the property North of Lancaster Ave. To the south of the turnpike, the estate included several acres of undeveloped forest which still exist today.

Between 1900 and 1908, the estate went through two major changes. First, it passed to J. Johnson's daughter Martha M. Brown, who co-owned the property with Mary J. Chew. Second, the Philadelphia & Western Railway Company (founded 1902) built a line that ran through the forest to the south of the turnpike.

By 1937, the land had passed fully into the Chew family's hands. The estate was split up and portions were owned by Oswald and Ada K. Chew. The P&W railroad still ran through the forest, owned by Oswald.

SEPTA acquired P&W through various mergers in the following decades, converting one line into the R100. The line through the forest was abandoned in the early fifties and has since been reclaimed by nature. Today, as you walk through the woods, you come across a steep ridge running parallel to Lancaster Ave. roughly 300 feet to the south. A large cement tunnel betrays the ridge's manmade origin (the ridge would otherwise run straight through Ithan creek). On the top, no trace of the railway can be found -- not a single tie, track, or rail remains.

The land is now owned by the Radnor School district. The forest remains undeveloped, haunted by the remains of the railroad and (allegedly) the spirit of its eponymous owner, Martha Brown.
Source:
Properties along Pennsylvania Railroad, (Philadelphia, PA; J.L. Smith, 1900), plate 24. Housed in Haverford College Special Collections.

Atlas of Properties on Main Line Penna. Railroad from Overbrook to Paoli, (Philadelphia, PA: A.H. Mueller, 1908), plate 21. Housed in Haverford College Special Collections.

Atlas of the Properties in Lower Merion, Narberth, Haverford & Radnor Penna., (Philadelphia, PA: Franklin Survey Co., 1937), plate 35. Housed in Haverford College Special Collections.

Description:
Unlike Robert Hurst (See the entry An Orphan of Circumstance.), Clancy speaks of St. John’s with absolute nostalgia. The span of time from Thanksgiving to Christmas was especially nostalgic, according to the article, because “The Knights of Columbus would serve Thanksgiving dinner. Students from Villanova College would take the boys into town to see the wonders of John Wanamaker’s, Lit Brothers, Gimbel’s, or Strawbridge and Clothier; buy them a gift and treat them to dinner at the Horn & Hardart’s Automat. And of course, there were always holiday carols.” In addition, Clancy fondly remembers his stays with the host family during the holidays: “My memories of spending Christmas, Easter holidays and summer vacations with the Macatees are especially nostalgic and I have had a close relationship with that family ever since.” 
Further, Clancy denies that he grew up deprived or traumatized, claiming instead that he had a good childhood. When questioned about his opinion the criticism of orphanages, he answers, “Was I unfortunate …? Not hardly! Not when I review the ravages of our drug-infested society, particularly among inner-city youths, and the scourge it has placed upon us as a nation. Not when we witness the utter deprivement of little children whose psyches are wrecked by the proliferation of divorce, or broken homes, or child abuse from emotionally troubled parents, or in some cases to be brutally mutilated or even killed. Add to this the unsettling trauma of abortion and it becomes a pretty sordid state of affairs we find in our midst.” 

It is worthwhile to note that this article appears on website for Catholic news in the Philadelphia. A reading of the full article does reveal a bias towards an overly positive view of Catholic orphanages, not only through Clancy’s nostalgic testimony, but also by dismissing criticism of the orphanage upbringing as “common misconceptions”. Further, numerous stories found on the blog, Facebook page, and other social media dedicated to St. John’s suggest the exact opposite. Perhaps Clancy’s case is a special one.
Source: Baldwin, Lou. “Catholic Author Taps Fond Memories of Orphanage, Now Captures Finest Christmas Carols.” Catholic Philly, December 21, 2012. http://catholicphilly.com/2012/12/news/local-news/local-catholic-news/catholic-author-taps-fond-memories-of-orphanage-captures-finest-christmas-carols/.

Description:
"A comparative newcomer to the study of Philippine ornis, he has amassed at the Delaware Museum of Natural History, which he founded, one of the finest collections of Philippine birds in existence. Of course, some specimens are absent, as they would be in any museum, but Mr. duPont has diligently sought them out in other institutions. He has also led significant expeditions in the Philippines, starting in 1958; and anyone who knows John duPont will realize that once in the islands, he heads for the nearest mountains and jungles: he is not one to dawdle about in the gardens of local officials."(vi)


Thus reads the penultimate paragraph of the forward to John Eleuthere duPont's book, Philippine Birds, published in 1971. At first glance the almost 500 page tome dedicated to pictures and descriptions of the birds of the Philippines (scans attached), seems to offer little insight into the author himself. However, unpacking the sheer existence of this book makes possible a value entry into the man that is John duPont.

"A comparative newcomer," duPont is not a traditional academic. This book, the first of a number he writes, is published by the Delaware Museum of Natural History, a museum he himself financed and founded. Furthermore, duPont "has also led significant expeditions in the Philippines," horizontally integrating all aspects of the academic process, self financing every step from research through publication. Perhaps to be understood as a selfless dedication to Nscience this domination over every level of production is undoubtedly somewhat strange. What drives a man to build a home for his own findings, to build a publishing house for his own distribution. Much like the nouveau rich buying their way into class and fame, duPont can be seen as buying himself into the world of ornthology, yet far from being nouveau riche duPont comes from old money, but not old academic prestige. 


Furthermore the last sentence, that duPont heads straight to the mountains and is "not one to dawdle about," seems to do little more than pander to duPont's own self image. It seems difficult to read narcissism out of an anthology of birds yet there appears no other way to understand this strange tome.
Source: Philippine Birds, John Eleuthere du Pont,  Delaware Museum of Natural History; 1st edition (1971)
Title: Philippine Birds: reading narcissism from a book of birds
tags: book

Description:
"The Philippines, notwithstanding their close association over the years with the United States, are not yet within the ken of the recently popular organized bird tours. This is unfortunate, because the rich tropical forests on which the choicer elements in the animal and plant life of these islands depend is being destroyed at an appalling rate. When timber is being slashed off and shipped, not merely to factories in the Philippines but to the United States and Japan, what can be expected? A legacy of erosion and floods will follow to haunt later generations; meanwhile the wildlife is gone forever. But while the islands remain off the beaten track of the bird tours, who can speak out against the unnatural pillage? If the present publication can help to halt such trends, even in a small way, it will be one of its most important services" (vi).

Thus concludes the forward to John duPont's book, Philippine Birds, a weighty tome documenting the ornithological diversity of the Philippines. This single paragraph, appearing on one of three pages not dedicated to pictures or descriptions of exotic birds, contains referents to two of the great evils of capitalism, the subjugation of people and the subjugation of the environment. The entire violent, ugly, history of relations between the U.S. and the Philippines is wrapped up in the single sentence: "The Philippines, notwithstanding their close association over the years with the United States." This exemplifies Benjamin's concept of history, notably that the past cannot be delineated from the present. Historical violence bleeds into dry forwards of bird anthologies. 

How does this allusion of physical human violence compare to the actual description of "timber being slashed off," the violence inflicted upon the environment in the name of industry, played out through the destruction of the habitats of the birds duPont set out to classify?

This acknowledgement of environmental destruction thus completes the metaphorical cycle that brought John duPont to the Philippines to write this book in the first place. The existence of this book, the wealth requisite to fund duPont's foray into ornithology, is predicated upon an economic system that, understood to its full extent, necessitates "a legacy of erosion and floods," that doom these birds worth studying, stuffing and shipping around the world, to extinction.  Contextualizing duPont's book forces one to ackwnoledge the self-constructed nature versus industry dichotomy at the heart of the modern era.
Source: Philippine Birds, John Eleuthere du Pont,  Delaware Museum of Natural History; 1st edition (1971)
Title: Philippine Birds: reading cycles of capitalism from a book of birds

Description:
A.J. Cassatt formed the Lancaster Avenue Improvement Company to prevent trolley lines extending into the suburbs.

He totally rebuilds Lancaster Avenue between 52nd street and Paoli, making it a viable pathway to suburbia, yet"the remaining portion of the road, namely, that between Berwyn and Paoli, runs so close to the Pennsylvania Railroad that it is but little traveled and hence we have simply made such repairs upon it as were necessary to keep it safe." In other words, Cassatt repairs the section of the road where his competitors want to build a trolley line, but doesn't rebuild the road where his company, the Pennsylvania Railroad, already has a presence. 

Formation of built environment dictated by economic interests of Cassatt. What might West Philadelphia have looked like had Cassatt not blocked the spread of public transportation to this region in 1889? This class might not exist if Lancaster Avenue only started in Paoli.

Spread of railroads, thanks to Pennsylvania Railroad company and A.J. Cassatt, sent Lancaster Avenue into disrepair, but due to economic competition they ultimately save this stretch of the road, perhaps keeping it viable until spread of automobiles makes the road relevant again some 50 years later.
Source:
Haverford College Special Collections, Joshua Bailey Collection, D. Letters to Joshua L. Baily, 29. From Cassatt, A.J. Raverford, Pa., July 29, 1892.

Description:
A piece of creative writing, "The Universal Robot Company" by Anya Feinblitt or Helen Finkel:

“Out of a wilderness full of sunshine, vast plains, thick forests, velvety meadows, all covered with colorful skies, was our modern civilization born. 
Man the toiler of the lands on of the soil the slow moving human being twisted and turned, twitched and cracked until transformed to the mechanic, the builder, the creator, the laborer of to-day.
The vast planes thick forrests [sic] , velvety meadows disappeared miraculously over night. In their places, condensed populous cities, smoky factories, roaring elevator. Gigantic skyscrapers higher and higher, the wheel of machinery faster, faster, the noise and roar louder and louder. Higher, faster, louder faster no time to breathe, no time to think, no time to live, but on and on.
Produce, create, labor hard, harder, harder, old, outworn, out of order, out he goes. It s much cheaper to replace him, by a new young worker, robot, than to restore the old out worn body with new parts.
More and more goods were produced; a surplus of everything beginning with the necessities and ending with the beautiful things in the arts.
A customer was needed, a glutton to devour the surplus. Here was a huge bulk of thinkingless, feelingless, tasteless worker, robots on hand.
A movement started to introduce the bulk, the glutton to the fine and dainty things in life. The incredible happened.
The glutton awakened. It started to think, feel, develop a taste and desire for the fine and beautiful.
It started to demand the rights to live, and demanded more and more.
Disturbances occurred, but they were squelched. The masters were horrified, what had they done? They had put a human living soul in the robot. How take it back? [sic]
It was too late.
The worker-robot, dressed as a soldier, sailor, guardsman, had power for he was well trained to fight.
On a clear morning after a heavy storm, the sunbeams that succeeded in penetrating the thickly set skyscrapers, set eyes on the new masters.
Heavy set men with powerful muscles, sun burned and wind beaten faces. Hair tangled, but heads up, some what startled, a little frightened at the chaotic place they’d found.
Louder blew the whistle, cheerfully hissed the engine, faster and livelier turned the wheel of the machine. Robots happy.
The wheel of the machine of the world was the powerful hand of its master-Labor."
Source: "The Universal Robot Company," 1927-1932. Box 1, Folder 27, Rita Rubinstein Heller Collection on the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry, Bryn Mawr College.

Description:
Dear Sirs:

       As Chairman of the Board of Visitors appointed by the Board of Judges too visit institution where children are committed in Philadelphia County, I desire to call your attention to the following which appears in the report for your institution:

            “Forty children use the swimming pool at a time and the sister in charge of the group is present whenever her group is  in the water, There is no lifesaver on duty when the pool is being used. The end of the pool is reserved for the older boys. There is no swimming instruction given and no buddy system or other means of check-up other than the sister’s presence is used. Under these circumstances, the use of the pool seems definitely hazardous.

            “It seems to be indicated that social service  or a psychiatric worker could well be used in this situation.

            “It would seem obvious that where there are 340 court cases involving children from broken homes that a highly trained and skilled psychologist would contribute greatly to their welfare and development

             “Toilet facilities seemed inadequate. The vast number of children sleeping in a single dormitory is certainly undesirable.”

I trust you will give this matter your attention. Thanking you for your courtesy, I am

                                              Yours sincerely,

                                            JOHN W. LORD, JR.,
                                                Chairman
Source: Lord, Jr., John W. Official Letter, April 26, 1949. PAHRC.

Description:
A manuscript, unpublished(?), typewritten:
No Malory of old romance,
	No Crusoe tale, it seems to me,
Can equal in rich circumstance
	This telephone directory.

No ballad of fair ladies’ eyes,
	No legend of proud knights and dames,
Can fill me with such bright surmise
	As this great book of numbered names!

How many hearts and lives unknown,
	Rare damsels pining for a squire,
Are waiting for the telephone
	To ring, and call them to the wire.

Some wait to hear a loved voice say
	The news they will rejoice to know
At Rome 2637J
	Or Marathon 1450!

And some, perhaps, are stung with fear
	And go with apprehensive tread:
The message they expect to hear
	Means life or death or daily bread.

A million hearts here wait our call,
	All naked to our distant speech ---
I wish that I could sing them all
	And have some welcome news for each!

Description:
Stanza from poem published in Lancaster Ave. News by Douglass Malloch, titled "Virtue."

They call it virtue--to set teeth,
        Square shoulders, wear a smile
When grief is gnawing underneath,
         Some sorrow, all the while.
They call it virtue--not to speak,
      Ask comfort, or complain,
Yes, even when the heart grows weak 
     With weariness or pain.

They call it virtue--yet I doubt
     If we need doubt so much
The brotherhood of those about
    We must not tell or touch
They call it virtue--thus to bear
     Our burdens all alone,
And yet I doubt if none would care,
   If other hearts are stone

They call it virtue--yet I know 
     The world is much more kind,
Is quick its fellowship to show 
   To burdened heart or mind.
They call it virtue--it may be
    A selfishness, a sin,
To doubt all human sympathy,
    And hide the hurt within

The havoc wreaked by Stock Market Crash demands reassessment of  nature of virtue itself.
Source: Lancaster Ave. News [Philadelphia] January 10. 1932. Print.

Description:
In 1937, Margaretta Hinchman strolled through Haverford's campus and recorded her impressions of several of the trees. Perhaps remembered hours later (it is unlikely she carried a typewriter with her), the wide range of observations is instructive to understanding the perception of nature along modern Lancaster Avenue.

Some entries are pseudo-scientific in their objectivity. Take the following: "6. A Group of Elms — Six Elms, 3 English 3 American" and "2. Oak on Quad. — As Broad as it is Long." Simulated nature allows for man to know and control the natural spaces around which would otherwise prove daunting in their vacuum-like meaninglessness.

Other entries read as charmingly absurd, such as "8. White Pine, Entrance to Bird Sanctuary — The Birds' Xmas Candles which are lighted in June." Even more entries exhibit a certain playfulness: "4. Osage Orange — Playground of the Professor's Children" and "15. Group of Tulip Poplars — A shady nook that calls for a Book." Since simulated nature is an environment controlled by man, what would otherwise be seen as a paranormal threat to the rational understandings of modernity becomes instead a benign flight of fancy. 

The distinction of simulated versus genuine natural space is recorded outright in Hinchman's observations as well. "10. Two Tulips, — Nature's Gateposts, entrance to woods beyond the farm." creates the cognitive divide between the two types of natural space by invoking the liminality of a gateway. The stark contrast between woods and farmland too serves to illuminate the vastly different experiences of genuinely natural versus simulated natural spaces.
Source: Margaretta S. Hinchman, Trees on the Haverford College Grounds, unpublished, in Haverford College Special Collections.
Title: Reflections about Haverford's Trees

Philadelphia ex-policeman and former president of the Fraternal Order of Police, Robert Hurst, recounted the traumatic toll the asylum had on his emotional growth in the entry Orphan of Circumstance. Out of the few positive memories he had of St. Johns, the strongest was of a Sister Egberta McGee, whose warmth and kindness was able to brighten his otherwise dreary childhood:  “Small woman, dribbled from her mouth when she taught, but she'd grab you by the face and hold you close and say, 'God love you.' She showed affection to me. Even when you did something wrong, she'd hit you softly and then she'd reach way down into her habit, down near her shoes, and give you some hard candy with fuzz balls on it. She was so good, so loving. . . . ".
It is no coincidence then that, years later, a newspaper photographer captured Hurst and other former inmates paying their respects at the grave of Sister Egberta.
Source: Dubin, Murray. “Growing Up In An Orphanage: Two Men And One Woman Look Back To The Years They Spent There. They Got Everything They Needed - Except Love.” Philly.com, January 11, 1995. http://articles.philly.com/1995-01-11/living/25711790_1_orphanage-sisters-teenage-mothers.

Description:
Sun Bathers
Vera Chandler

On top of the Bryn Mawr Gymnasium is a flat roof with a three-foot wall around it. This roof is used by the students to take sun baths. One day several girls went rushing up, all talking and laughing at the same time.

‘My goodness! What a hot place!’
‘Say, you didn’t expect it to be cold, did you?’
‘No, but I didn’t think it would be like this. Look at the floor, how bare and dirty it is. Why don’t they put some rugs out here for us to sit on?’
‘Sit on! Oh, you give me a pain. You don’t think you’re going to sit up, do you?’
“Yes.”
‘Well, you won’t. come on and let’s fix up some cots to lie down on.’
‘Ouch! This floor feels like an oven! I’ll be stewing in a minute.’
‘Oh, that’s nothing. I’ll bet I can fry eggs on my back right now.’
‘Look’, exclaimed a red-haired girl. ‘Look at the freckles on my back! It makes me cross-eyed trying to count them.’
‘Don’t try, then. It’s impossible, anyway. Every time I look at you I think I am looking through a muddy windshield.’
‘When I look at you I feel like laughing. See that person over there in the corner? You look just like her.’
‘What’s wrong with her?’
‘Those legs—like a giraffe’s neck when he’s swallowed an alarm-clock that won’t go down right.’
‘Well! What about yourself?’
‘Oh, I’m all right.’
‘All right! Don’t be so funny—‘
‘Listen, I hear something’, said a girl in the corner who had been quiet all this time. ‘it’s an airplane flying low. Come on girls, make a dive for the door.’"
Source: Chandler, Vera. "Sun Bathers," in OUTCROP, 1929, Box 1, Folder 27. Rita Rubinstein Heller Collection on the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry. Bryn Mawr College Special Collections, Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA.
Title: Sunbathing--risk of airplanes will apply

Description: In one of his college writing assignments: “The Character of Benjamin Franklin typifies American human nature of the Eighteenth Century. Tho’ of inconspicuous origin, and passing his earlier life among vagabonds, by strict attention to business and by his inborn common-sense, he gradually raised himself above his level. His character may be described as strictly materialistic and rationalistic—and this may be very well shown by his religious feelings. He judged religion by its effects on every-day life and conduct. Unlike his contemporaries he devoted more time to the study of earthly accomplishment than to the relation of man to eternity. Franklin gave a great deal of shrewd thought to the morals of this life, and compiled many popular aphorisms—also his list of virtues and ‘Rules of Conduct.’ His nature was not without humor—but of that kind which, as Macaulay says ‘throws a double portion of severity into his countenance while laughing inwardly.’”

Description:
Christopher Morley in college on daydreaming as idling: "We should not let a day pass without both physical and mental exercise. But, just as rest is necessary after physical labor, so we need recreation and relaxation from mental strain. And where can we find this better than in day dreams? in this Poet’s No-Man’s Land of the imagination where we cast off the shackles of What Is and revel in delicious dreams of What Might Be.
	But day-dreams are properly of two kinds—those of the Idle Fancy, and Dreams of Unrealized Possibility, both of which let us glance at.
	In the dreams of Idle Fancy we become children again in spirit. We ourselves embody all our ideals—we imagine ourselves as heroes. These dreams have no correspondence in reality—there are merely the instinctive flight of the soul from the humdrum round of daily life. If not indulged in too extravagantly these dreams have a tonic and recreative effect on the mind.
	Daydreams of Unrealized possibility are rather different. They always look forward to the future, and deal with the actual realization of Ideals—they are possible. They are a mental stimulus and inspiration, and are really prophetic visions which contain “the seed of future good and future need.” And so we see that in our day-dreams we are able to get outside of ourselves and follow the sunset, so that we may always see the world bathed in a mellow golden splendor. Hard, cold, stern realities are laid aside, and our pleasure is bounded only by the confines of our imagination." Imagination as a tool to vivify the sternness of reality.
Source: Christopher Morley, "Day Dreams as a Mental Recreation," October 28, 1907
Title: Daydreams as a Mental Recreation

Description: From Christopher Morley's draft of his essay on humor: “Every one, except my wife, has always credited me with having a satisfactorily high voltage of humour. The question of how to appear humorous to one’s wife is a problem whose solution I am unable to approach. Before we were married I used to go to call on her, and take with me orchids, chocolates, theater tickets, and other small talk of that kind, and she always laughed with a will at these witticisms. But now I struggle home through the suburban snowdrifts freighted with machine oil for the baby or flannel petticoats for the lawn mower, and I never raise a single guffaw.” Marriage took away humor.
Source: Christopher Morley, "A Gossip about Humour," 1916, 2.
Title: High voltage of humor and marriage

Description: Another fecund source of merriment: “last wills and testaments:” “The elderly aunt who has willed all her money to you, and then gets a paralytic stroke, is one of the most truly humorous figures in the world. This matter of being kind to people who are about to make a will has always appealed me strongly. I see in the papers that a young lady, strolling three years ago by the surf at Revere Beach, saw an elderly woman stumble in the sand. She assisted her to her feet, lent her a slab of reviving pepsis, and powdered her nose for her. Now the old lady has died and left the young person three thousand dollars. I hurried to Revere Beach as soon as I read the article, but although I patrolled the sand all day, no one stumbled.”

Description: Stephen Leacock was a humorous writer who was widely read. He had correspondence with Morley, who was fond of quoting him when he discussed humor: “Professor Leacock, in his very delightful essay on American Humour (his his volume “Essays and and Literary Studies”) tells us that the basis of our sense of humour lies in the incongruity, the unfittingness, the want of harmony among things. … A realization of contrast between the ideal and the actual is then at the root of our sense of humour; particularly when the contrast flashes on us suddenly and unexpectedly, and is thus enhanced by the shock of surprise. Laughter is our unexplained but immediate physical reaction. In all probability we do not laugh because anything is funny: we realize it is funny because we find ourselves laughing”
Source: Christopher Morley, "A Gossip about Humour," 1916, 5–6.
Title: Christopher Morley's Stephen Leacock

Description:
Column reads: 

"Miss Alice Rise, 18, of 5126 Hioopes street, a graduate from the Overbrook High School last June and who was taking an evening language course, was struck and injured fatally about 9 o'clock Monday night by an automobile as she started to run across Lancaster avenue, in front of the school near Fifty-ninth street.

Miss Rice, hurrying to avoid being late for class, did not see an automobile driven by Sivlio Martucci, 23 of Avon road, Ardmore, approaching. In the car with Martucci, was his brother, Pietro its ownder. 

Miss Rice was struck and knocked about twenty-five feet. A passing motorist took her to Misericordia Hospital where she died shortly before 10 o'clock as a result of internal injuries. Silvio Martucci was held for manslaughter and his brother was slated as a material witness."

Description:
A creative remix based upon my research paper on St. John's Orphan Asylum. It is an attempt to reflect on the following questions: What would a boy admitted to St. John's have brought with him? Why? The images on the lid of the suitcase are a mix of actual photos from St. John's, Catholic iconography, and pop culture, and are designed to simulate the memories or moments captured during a boy's stay at the asylum

Description:
The Suntop Home in Ardmore was built by Frank Lloyd Wright as a prototype for his theoretical Broadacre city.

Exploring the possibilities of communal housing Wright built a beautiful four family home; the unique design affording each family dignity through private space. 

Built in 1939 as a planned one of four quadruple homes, the project was canceled due to the escalation of World War Two, and the complaint's of neighbors who opposed multi-family housing coming to Ardmore. 

The failure of the Suntop project actualized the failure of Wright's larger Broadacre project, and in a broader sense, the failure of suburbia. 

The Suntop homes inhabit an alternate reality where public, communal housing and intelligent suburban development flourished into more beautiful forms. They represent the glimmer of an un-actualized development peaking through our current history. 

Through this, they become a Benjaminian anecdote for what could have been. Capitalism produced Frank Lloyd Wright, offered beautiful urban planning, and instead that energy was thrown away amidst World War Two and the ensuring conflicts that literally sucked the lifeblood out of Wright's imagined possibilities.
Source:
Lower Merion Conservancy 
http://lmconservancy.org/suntop-homes/
Title: Suntop Home by Frank Lloyd Wright: apotheosis of suburbia

"Sophie: As a worker it left but one question in my mind. How can we help them to obtain a decent living?.

Elsie: Everything is weighed and measured by a few for a few to get perfect production. But the body of man is not considered. Men working in two shifts, day and night, twelve hours a day, bathe in sweat from facing the forever burning furnaces where men claim that although we are tortured by you, we cannot do without you. Women mothers, women teachers, women workers, the future of the world is in our hands. Let us all unite and free our men from slavery.

Bertha: Man power, machinery, Coal, Ore, Electricity, capital, Capitalism, shareholders, skyscrapers, weapons, battle ships, waste, beyond human endurance, Dante’s Inferno.

Clara:  I don’t know what to say about the steel mill. All I could see was stoel, [sic] red hot and burning all the time. Workers are working very hard all the time, no shirts on their bodies, the day is long, gloomy, and tiresome. There is no time to think of anything but steel. Why do workers have to live like this and for what! For a dry piece of bread and a shelter to live. Aren’t they entitled to anything better for enslaving themselves twelve hours a day, in the hot burning furnaces which melt the steel. Will this ever come to an end. Description:
Cultural exchange was commonplace at the summer school. While different tastes in dances, songs, and culture could cause conflict, often these differences would erode and result in a mutual informing and sharing. Dean of students Hilda Smith remembers:
"[There was a] Russian Jewish girl, and just above her was a Southern cotton worker, and they were very antagonistic. And they both happened to be musical, and [the girl] from the south, (I forget the name of the Russian girl), but one of them began to play Russian folk songs. The American southern worker objected very much. She said she was terrible, she couldn’t stand the music. They were right over one over the other and it got to be quite a personal controversy…and finally, the Russian girl went and knocked on the door of the southern cotton mill worker, and asked her if she would teach her some of the southern folk songs. And, in return, finally, the cotton mill worker asked her to teach her some of the Russian folk songs. So you had this very good concert, both of them together. And they sang each others songs.”  
from: Transcript of interview with Eleanoir Coit, Hilda Smith, and others, 1976, Box 2, Folder 1. Rita Rubenstein Heller Collection on the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry.

Description:
John duPont's eccentric obsessions, ranging from birds and stamps to swimming and wrestling, are well documented, as was duPont's lonely childhood. However, the connection between the two receives scant little attention. 

The duPont's family driver, Mr. Cherry, became a quasi father figure for John, who was raised by his single mother. 

Mr. Cherry drove John to the Haverford Boy's school, where John attended school, dropping off his own son, referred to as Hubie throughout duPont's autobiography, at the local public school Haverford High. 

This car ride, and John's interaction with Mr. Cherry and his son Hubie, become incredibly formative to John. Mr. Cherry introduces John to ornithology and the natural sciences in general, which become lifelong obsession's of John's, culminating in the creation of the Delaware Museum of Natural History.  Meanwhile, Hubie, competing in swimming and wrestling, inspires John's lasting interesting in both sports.
Source: Turkington, Carol. No Holds Barred: The Strange Life of John E. DuPont. New York: Turner Publishing, 1996

Description: A summer school faculty member remembers: “The swimming pool at Bryn Mawr was presumably available for the summer school [sic]. But some limitations had been put on its use…the faculty was using the swimming pool fairly freely at various hours of the day and the students were not. Whether they were excluded is not clear to me but they, there were apparently some kind of separate and better privileges for faculty than for students. Some of the students, lead particularly by a recent lerman [sic] immigrant, protested and protested very vigorously. The result was that it was generally understood at the students’ insistence that there should be no faculty privileges not available to students and the result was of course that the pool was open to everyone on the same terms. I remember feeling some unease, or guilt, about the fact that I had used the pool under these early circumstances without much sense that I was depriving anybody of special privileges. I remember feeling that the student’s had thought faster and better than I had as a faculty member and I regretted this very much”

Description:
Never Before, by Rose Kurstin

"Never before outside of my public school days, have I had such an opportunity as this, -- to study, to play, to wonder, and to observe.

I feel as if my mind is cracking into pieces. My desire to learn is much greater than my mind can grasp. I feel as if time is rushing ahead of me, and I am almost out of breath to keep up. Some times I compare myself to a fertile soil which from lack of rain or sunshine had dried up a bit.

Often I ask myself, "Is it not too late for me? Will the spirit of Bryn Mawr help me to continue or will the daily struggle devour me again and crush in me my last strife for education?"

Description: "Advertising men are so slick and cubist nowadays that it is almost impolite to ask what is an advertisement and what is not. Also it is tactless to ask what it is that’s being advertised. Guess three times, and then reverse your decision. A picture of a tall man in knickerboxers striding across some bumpy country with a Russian wolf-hound turns out to be a boost for a cathartic---beg your pardon, an internal cleanser. A little essay on the evils of heavy drinking proves to be a whisky ad. And, after careful study, a kind of Le Gallienne essay on the fine flower of courtesy emanates into a puff for bituminous railway system. What if all this war should turn out to be merely press agent stuff for some new health resort?"
Source: Christopher Morley, "Advertising Men," undated.
